brief_description: Cathelicidins are small proteins in the human body that protect against infection. The purpose of this study is to determine if the amount of cathelicidins and other small proteins found in saliva can predict the amount of these in the skin of people who have acute atopic dermatitis (AD) or psoriasis.
brief_title: Analysis and Correlation of Cathelicidin Expression in Skin and Saliva of Subjects with Atopic Dermatitis and Psoriasis (CATH 02)
condition_studied: Subjects with Atopic Dermatitis, subjects with Psoriasis, generally healthy subejcts, subjects with Eczema Herpeticum
description:
People with AD or psoriasis are very sensitive to skin infections and inflammations. A group of small proteins known as cathelicidins are known to be responsible for immune defense against such infections. People with AD or psoriasis seem to be missing these proteins from their skin.

The purpose of this study is to determine if the amount of cathelicidins and other small proteins in saliva is a predictor for the amount found in the skin. This is a single visit observational study. People with AD or psoriasis, as well as healthy participants, are being recruited for this study. Participants will provide a detailed medical history and undergo a physical examination. In addition, saliva and blood collection, and skin punch biopsies will be performed.
endpoints:
1. To measure the local and systemic expression of cathelicidin (hCAP18/LL-37) in subjects with AD with and without EH, psoriasis, and in non-atopic controls.
  2. To determine whether the relative abundance of cathelicidins (hCAP18/LL-37) in the skin Correlates with the expression in saliva and/or blood.
hypothesis: The expression of  cathelicidin in saliva and/or blood can be used to predict the relative abundance of cathelicidin in skin of subjects with AD, psoriasis or non-atopic controls.
objectives:
Primary Objective:
To measure the local and systemic expression of cathelicidin (hCAP18/LL-37) in subjects with ADEH-, ADEH+, Psoriasis, and in non-atopic controls.

Secondary Objective:
To determine whether the relative abundance of cathelicidin in the skin correlates with expression in saliva and/or blood.
official_title: Analysis and Correlation of Cathelicidin Expression in Skin and Saliva of Subjects with Atopic Dermatitis and Psoriasis
